message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Understanding the Demographics of Twitter Users
Paper Abstract: Every second, the thoughts and feelings of millions of people across the world are recorded in the form of 140-character tweets using Twitter. However, despite the enormous potential presented by this remarkable data source, we still do not have an understanding of the Twitter population itself: Who are the Twitter users? How representative of the overall population are they? In this paper, we take the first steps towards answering these questions by analyzing data on a set of Twitter users representing over 1% of the U.S. population. We develop techniques that allow us to compare the Twitter population to the U.S. population along three axes (geography, gender, and race/ethnicity), and find that the Twitter population is a highly non-uniform sample of the population.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Search Results for "Social Media"

Here's an overview of social media based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

Social media platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.(no content)Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn.

### Key Functions

They may be used to promote people, companies, products, and ideas. Additionally, social media can be used to consume, publish, or share news.

### Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

### Global Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

### Differences from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

### Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_census"},{"title":"2020 United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_census"},{"title":"1910 United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1910_United_States_census"},{"title":"1880 United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1880_United_States_census"},{"title":"2000 United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_United_States_census"},{"title":"1980 United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_United_States_census"},{"title":"1840 United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1840_United_States_census"},{"title":"1830 United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1830_United_States_census"},{"title":"United States Census Bureau - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau"},{"title":"Race and ethnicity in the United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States_census"}]

## United States Census

Here's an overview of the United States Census based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose
The United States census is a decennial census that is legally mandated by the Constitution of the United States.(no content)The United States Census Bureau is responsible for conducting the census.

### History
The first census after the American Revolution was taken in 1790 under Secretary of State Thomas Jefferson.(no content)There have been 24 federal censuses since that time.(no content)The most recent national census took place in 2020; the next census is scheduled for 2030.

### 2020 Census
The census recorded a resident population of 331,449,281 in the 50 states and the national capital of Washington, D.C., reflecting an increase of 7.4%, or 22,703,743, over 2010 United States census.(no content)Other than a pilot study during the 2000 United States census, this was the first U.S. census to offer options to respond online or by phone, in addition to the paper response form used for previous censuses.

### Functions and Impact
Census results help determine how more than $675 billion in federal funding are allocated to states and communities each year for roads, schools, hospitals (health clinics), emergency services, and more.(no content)The results of the census are used to determine how many congressional districts each state is apportioned. Congress defines the formula, in accordance with Title 2 of the U.S. Code, to reapportion among the states the 435 seats in the United States House of Representatives.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Demographics"

Links: [{"title":"Demography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demography"},{"title":"Demographics of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"Demographics of the world - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_the_world"},{"title":"Demographics of New York City - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_New_York_City"},{"title":"Race and ethnicity in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Demographic statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographic_statistics"},{"title":"Category:Demographics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Demographics"},{"title":"Demographic profile - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographic_profile"},{"title":"List of demographics articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_demographics_articles"},{"title":"Demographics of Spain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Spain"}]

I've performed a web search for "Demographics" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here's what the search revealed:

## What is Demography?

Demography is the statistical study of human populations: their size, composition (e.g., ethnic group, age), and how they change through the interplay of fertility (births), mortality (deaths), and migration.(no content)Demographic analysis examines and measures the dimensions and dynamics of populations; it can cover whole societies or groups defined by criteria such as education, nationality, religion, and ethnicity.

## Demographic Statistics

Demographic statistics are measures of the characteristics of, or changes to, a population. Records of births, deaths, marriages, immigration and emigration and a regular census of population provide information that is key to making sound decisions about national policy.

## Global Population

Earth has a human population of over 8.2 billion as of 2025, with an overall population density of 50 people per km2.(no content)Nearly 60% of the world's population lives in Asia, with more than 2.8 billion in the countries of India and China combined.

## Applications of Demographics

A demographic profile is a form of demographic analysis in which information is gathered about a group to better understand the group's composition or behaviors for the purpose of providing more relevant services. In business, a demographic profile is usually used to increase marketing efficiency.

The search results provide a comprehensive overview of demographics as a field, its global statistics, and how it's applied in various contexts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Twitter"

Links: [{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"},{"title":"Twitter, Inc. - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter,_Inc."},{"title":"Twitter under Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Twitter Files - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_Files"},{"title":"Censorship of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Stan Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Twitter"},{"title":"History of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_Twitter_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"2020 Twitter account hijacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Twitter_account_hijacking"},{"title":"Twitter verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_verification"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Twitter:

## What is Twitter/X?

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service and one of the world's largest social media platforms and most-visited websites.(no content)Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts.

## History

Work on the project started in February 2006, with the first Twitter prototype developed by Jack Dorsey and contractor Florian Weber used as an internal service for Odeo employees, and the full version introduced publicly on July 15, 2006.(no content)Twitter spun off into its own company in April 2007.

## Recent Ownership Changes

The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established to succeed the prior owner Twitter, Inc. in March 2023 following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.(no content)Linda Yaccarino succeeded Musk as CEO on June 5, 2023, with Musk remaining as the chairman and the chief technology officer.(no content)In July 2025, Linda Yaccarino stepped down from her role as CEO.(no content)In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company, in an all-stock transaction valued at $33 billion, with a full valuation of $45 billion when factoring in $12 billion in debt.

## Rebranding

In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established to succeed the prior owner Twitter, Inc. in March 2023 following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.(no content)Linda Yaccarino succeeded Musk as CEO on June 5, 2023, with Musk remaining as the chairman and the chief technology officer.(no content)In July 2025, Linda Yaccarino stepped down from her role as CEO.(no content)In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company, in an all-stock transaction valued at $33 billion, with a full valuation of $45 billion when factoring in $12 billion in debt.

## Rebranding

In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about sampling bias:

## Definition

Sampling bias is a bias in which a sample is collected in such a way that some members of the intended population have a lower or higher sampling probability than others.(no content)It results in a biased sample of a population in which all individuals, or instances, were not equally likely to have been selected.

## Key Characteristics

If this is not accounted for, results can be erroneously attributed to the phenomenon under study rather than to the method of sampling.(no content)Sampling bias can lead to a systematic over- or under-estimation of the corresponding parameter in the population.

## Common Examples

Several examples illustrate how sampling bias occurs in practice:

- A survey of high school students to measure teenage use of illegal drugs will be a biased sample because it does not include home-schooled students or dropouts.

- A "man on the street" interview which selects people who walk by a certain location is going to have an overrepresentation of healthy individuals who are more likely to be out of the home than individuals with a chronic illness.

- Self-selection bias is possible whenever the group of people being studied has any form of control over whether to participate. Participants' decision to participate may be correlated with traits that affect the study, making the participants a non-representative sample. For example, people who have strong opinions or substantial knowledge may be more willing to spend time answering a survey than those who do not.

## Classification

Sampling bias is usually classified as a subtype of selection bias, sometimes specifically termed sample selection bias, but some classify it as a separate type of bias.(no content)Medical sources sometimes refer to sampling bias as ascertainment bias.

Perfect! All tasks are now complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Understanding the Demographics of Twitter Users" and extracted all key entities:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution paper (proposes new demographic analysis techniques)

**Extracted Triples:**

1. **Twitter** (tool) - The social media platform used as the data source for demographic analysis
2. **Demography** (concept) - The statistical study of population characteristics applied to Twitter users
3. **Social media** (tool) - The broader category of technology being studied
4. **United States census** (data) - The benchmark dataset used to assess how representative Twitter users are of the general U.S. population
5. **Sampling bias** (concept) - The novel finding that the paper proposes: identifying and quantifying the non-uniform sampling bias in Twitter's user demographics

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms the JSON is properly formatted with all required fields. The paper demonstrates a contribution by developing techniques to identify sampling bias in social media populations compared to census data.

Sources:
- [Twitter - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter)
- [Demography - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demography)
- [Social media - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media)
- [United States census - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_census)
- [Sampling bias - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_bias)
